name: Sickle Claw
description: Strike with your enlarged toe claw. 30% chance for double damage.
scientificNote: Deinonychus' sickle claw was held off the ground while running and deployed during attacks, similar to modern secretary birds.

scientificBasis.anatomicalSource: Deinonychus sickle claw measured approximately 12cm along the outer curve, hyperextensible at the second toe joint.
scientificBasis.behavioralInterpretation: Biomechanical studies suggest the claw was used for gripping and pinning prey rather than slashing, similar to accipitrid raptor predation.

gameTranslation.damageMultiplier: 1.0x base reflects controlled precision strikes rather than wild slashing
gameTranslation.criticalChance: 30% critical represents successful deployment of the hyperextended claw into vulnerable areas
gameTranslation.staminaCost: 30 stamina reflects the muscular effort required to maintain grip during prey restraint

name: Pack Coordination
description: Passive: Deal 20% bonus damage when above 80% health.
scientificNote: Fossil evidence from the Cloverly Formation suggests Deinonychus hunted in coordinated groups, targeting larger prey.

name: Feathered Agility
description: Passive: +2 evasion chance.
scientificNote: Feathers provided insulation and may have aided in balance during quick movements and leaps.

name: Leaping Strike
description: Leap at your target, dealing 150% damage. Ignores terrain penalties.
scientificNote: Dromaeosaurids likely used their strong legs to leap onto prey, using their claws to hold on while attacking.

name: Coordinated Assault
description: Strike in concert with pack members. Deals bonus damage for each ally in combat.
scientificNote: Pack hunting allowed dromaeosaurids to take down prey many times their own size.

name: Tail Club Counter
description: Counter 40% of incoming melee damage back to attacker.
scientificNote: Ankylosaurus' tail club could swing with approximately 14,000 Newtons of force, enough to break the leg bones of a T. rex.

scientificBasis.anatomicalSource: Tail club formed from fused osteoderms and enlarged caudal vertebrae, weighing approximately 5kg at the distal end.
scientificBasis.behavioralInterpretation: Biomechanical modeling estimates swing velocity of 60 km/h and impact force of 14,000+ Newtons, exceeding bone fracture thresholds for tyrannosaur tibiae.

gameTranslation.counterMechanic: 40% reflect represents the devastating defensive weapon - attackers risk serious injury
gameTranslation.damageType: Crushing damage reflects blunt force trauma from solid bone club
gameTranslation.staminaCost: 40 stamina reflects the muscular effort of swinging 5kg of fused bone

name: Fortify
description: Increase defense by 5 for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Ankylosaurus could hunker down, presenting only its armored dorsal surface to attackers.

name: Armored Hide
description: Passive: Reduce all incoming damage by 3.
scientificNote: Bony osteoderms covered most of Ankylosaurus' body, embedded in the skin like natural chain mail.

name: Immovable
description: Passive: Cannot be flanked or surprised. Immune to knockback.
scientificNote: With its low center of gravity, wide stance, and heavy armor, Ankylosaurus was extremely difficult to overturn.

name: Ground Pound
description: Slam the ground, stunning nearby enemies for 1 turn.
scientificNote: The massive weight of ankylosaurs could create significant ground vibrations when they moved.

name: Osteoderm Defense
description: Passive: 20% chance to completely negate physical attacks.
scientificNote: Osteoderms are bony deposits that form scales, plates, or other structures in the dermal layers of the skin.

name: Aerial Scout
description: Reveal the next 2 encounters on the map. Can only be used outside combat.
scientificNote: Pteranodon's excellent vision and high-altitude flight allowed it to spot prey and threats from great distances.

name: Dive Attack
description: Strike from above. Always goes first in combat turn. Deals 150% damage.
scientificNote: Pteranodon could build tremendous speed in a dive, using gravity to accelerate toward fish near the surface.

name: Escape Flight
description: Flee from combat without penalty. Always succeeds.
scientificNote: Flight gave pterosaurs unmatched mobility and escape options unavailable to ground-bound dinosaurs.

name: Thermal Soaring
description: Passive: Regenerate 5 stamina per turn while above 50% health.
scientificNote: Large pterosaurs like Pteranodon could soar on thermal updrafts for hours with minimal energy expenditure.

name: Fish Snatch
description: Quick attack that heals for 50% of damage dealt against aquatic targets.
scientificNote: Pteranodon was a piscivore, skimming the surface of the Western Interior Seaway to catch fish.

name: First Strike
description: Passive: Always act first on turn 1 of combat.
scientificNote: Aerial predators rely on surprise and speed to catch prey before it can react.

name: Evasive
description: Passive: +3 evasion chance.
scientificNote: Pteranodon's maneuverability in flight, controlled by its head crest and wing membrane, made it difficult to catch.

name: Hollow Bones
description: Passive: +2 speed but -5 max health.
scientificNote: Pterosaur bones were hollow and thin-walled, reducing weight for flight but making them more fragile.

name: Crushing Bite
description: Devastating bite attack. 200% damage but costs 50 stamina.
scientificNote: T. rex's bite force of 12,800 pounds was the strongest of any land animal, capable of crushing solid bone.

scientificBasis.anatomicalSource: Bite force estimated at 12,800 pounds (57,000 Newtons) based on skull biomechanics and muscle reconstruction.
scientificBasis.behavioralInterpretation: Coprolite evidence shows T. rex crushed and digested bone. Bite marks on Triceratops and Edmontosaurus bones confirm bone-crushing feeding behavior.

gameTranslation.damageMultiplier: 2.0x damage represents the most powerful bite of any land animal in Earth's history
gameTranslation.staminaCost: 50 stamina reflects enormous muscular effort - bite muscles comprised 8% of body mass
gameTranslation.cooldown: 3-turn cooldown represents the recovery time between maximum-force bites

name: Terrifying Roar
description: Reduce enemy attack by 3 for 3 turns. May cause fear.
scientificNote: As an apex predator, T. rex's presence alone would intimidate most creatures in its ecosystem.

name: Apex Strike
description: Massive attack dealing 250% damage. 5 turn cooldown.
scientificNote: T. rex could deliver devastating attacks with its massive jaws, lined with serrated teeth up to 30cm long.

name: Bone Crusher
description: Target's defense is permanently reduced by 2 for this combat.
scientificNote: T. rex coprolites (fossilized feces) contain pulverized bone, showing they crushed and digested bone matter.

name: Relentless Pursuit
description: Cannot be escaped from. Deals bonus damage to fleeing targets.
scientificNote: T. rex's binocular vision and keen sense of smell made it excellent at tracking prey over long distances.

name: Binocular Vision
description: Passive: +10% accuracy and +10% critical chance.
scientificNote: T. rex had forward-facing eyes with overlapping fields of view, providing depth perception better than a hawk's.

name: Keen Smell
description: Passive: Detect hidden enemies. Bonus damage against bleeding targets.
scientificNote: T. rex's olfactory bulbs were enormous, giving it a sense of smell rivaling modern vultures.

name: Aquatic Ambush
description: From water: Deal 180% damage and apply bleeding. Must be in water terrain.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus was adapted for aquatic hunting, with dense bones for buoyancy control and a crocodile-like snout.

scientificBasis.anatomicalSource: 2020 research revealed paddle-like tail with tall neural spines, dense pachyostotic bones for buoyancy control, and pressure-sensing neurovascular foramina on the snout.
scientificBasis.behavioralInterpretation: Spinosaurus likely hunted from the water using ambush tactics, similar to modern crocodilians. Conical teeth optimized for gripping slippery prey.

gameTranslation.damageMultiplier: 1.8x reflects the devastating surprise advantage of aquatic ambush predation
gameTranslation.bleedingEffect: 80% bleed chance represents the tearing damage from conical teeth designed for grip not cutting
gameTranslation.terrainRequired: Water terrain requirement reflects Spinosaurus' specialized semi-aquatic hunting strategy

name: Sail Display
description: Display your massive sail to intimidate. Reduces enemy attack and defense by 2.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus' sail could reach 1.8 meters tall and may have been used for display, thermoregulation, or fat storage.

name: Crocodilian Snap
description: Quick bite attack with high accuracy. 20% chance to stun.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus' long, narrow snout was similar to modern gharials, ideal for catching slippery fish.

name: Tail Propulsion
description: Use your paddle tail to quickly reposition. Gain +3 speed for 2 turns.
scientificNote: 2020 research revealed Spinosaurus had a paddle-like tail adapted for swimming, confirming its aquatic lifestyle.

name: Semi-Aquatic
description: Passive: +50% damage and +3 defense in water terrain. Can breathe underwater.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus is the only known dinosaur adapted for a primarily aquatic lifestyle.

name: Pressure Sensors
description: Passive: Detect movement in water. Cannot be surprised in water terrain.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus' snout had small pits that may have detected pressure waves, similar to crocodilian integumentary sensors.

name: Skull Bash
description: Headbutt dealing 130% damage with high stun chance.
scientificNote: Pachycephalosaurus' dome skull was up to 25cm thick, though debate continues whether it was used for head-butting.

name: Charging Headbutt
description: Charge at enemy dealing 160% damage. Self-damage: 5.
scientificNote: The skull dome was surrounded by bony knobs and short spikes that may have absorbed impact shock.

name: Thick Skull
description: Passive: Immune to stun effects. +5% damage reduction from head attacks.
scientificNote: The pachycephalosaur skull dome was solid bone, unlike most dinosaur skulls which had air spaces.

name: Giant Sickle Claw
description: Strike with your massive toe claw. 40% critical chance, 200% critical damage.
scientificNote: Utahraptor's sickle claw was 24cm long - twice the size of Deinonychus' and capable of devastating wounds.

name: Alpha Strike
description: Lead your pack in a devastating coordinated attack. All allies attack the same target.
scientificNote: The Stikes Quarry in Utah preserved multiple Utahraptor specimens together, suggesting pack behavior.

name: Pack Rally
description: Boost all allies' attack and speed by 3 for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Pack coordination allows predators to take down prey much larger than any individual could manage.

name: Scythe Slash
description: Sweep with your meter-long claws dealing 140% damage to all enemies.
scientificNote: Therizinosaurus had the longest claws of any known animal - up to 1 meter (3.3 feet) long.

name: Defensive Sweep
description: Sweep claws to create distance. Pushes enemies back and prevents approach for 1 turn.
scientificNote: Despite being an herbivore, Therizinosaurus' claws made it extremely dangerous to predators.

name: Longest Claws
description: Passive: +3 attack. Attacks have extended range.
scientificNote: The elongated claws were likely used to pull down tree branches and for defense against predators like Tarbosaurus.

name: Bull Rush
description: Charge at full speed. Deals 170% damage, ignores defense.
scientificNote: Carnotaurus was one of the fastest large theropods, possibly reaching 48 km/h (30 mph).

name: Horn Gore
description: Gore with your distinctive horns. Causes bleeding for 3 turns.
scientificNote: Carnotaurus means 'meat-eating bull', named for its distinctive horns above the eyes.

name: Rapid Strikes
description: Attack 3 times in quick succession. Each hit deals 50% damage.
scientificNote: Carnotaurus' lightweight build and strong legs allowed for quick, agile movements.

name: Speed Demon
description: Passive: Always act first. +2 speed.
scientificNote: Studies of Carnotaurus leg bones suggest it was optimized for speed over power.

name: Resonating Call
description: Use your crest to produce a booming call. Buffs allies and debuffs enemies for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Parasaurolophus' hollow crest could produce low-frequency sounds that traveled long distances.

scientificBasis.anatomicalSource: Hollow cranial crest contained convoluted nasal passages up to 1.8m in length, functioning as resonating chambers.
scientificBasis.behavioralInterpretation: Digital acoustic reconstruction produced sounds in the 30-240 Hz range. Low frequencies travel kilometers and could coordinate herd movements or warn of predators.

gameTranslation.allyBuffs: +2 attack/defense represents improved herd coordination from clear communication
gameTranslation.damageType: Sonic damage reflects the disorienting effect of powerful low-frequency sound on enemies
gameTranslation.cooldown: 4-turn cooldown represents the time needed to build breath pressure for another resonating call

name: Herd Warning
description: Sound an alarm call. All allies gain +50% damage on next attack.
scientificNote: Living in herds for protection, hadrosaurs likely had complex vocal communication.

name: Stampede
description: Lead a charge! Deal 120% damage and knock back enemies.
scientificNote: A stampeding hadrosaur herd would have been extremely dangerous to anything in their path.

name: Acute Hearing
description: Passive: Cannot be surprised. Detect hidden enemies.
scientificNote: The hollow crest also enhanced hearing, allowing hadrosaurs to detect predators from greater distances.

name: Precision Strike
description: Target a weak point. 50% critical chance, ignores 50% armor.
scientificNote: Troodon had one of the highest brain-to-body ratios of any dinosaur, suggesting advanced problem-solving.

name: Night Vision Hunt
description: Hunt under cover of darkness. +50% damage at night or in caves.
scientificNote: Troodon's large, forward-facing eyes suggest it was adapted for hunting in low light conditions.

name: Cunning Trap
description: Set a trap that triggers when enemy attacks. Counter with 150% damage.
scientificNote: High intelligence would have allowed Troodon to employ more sophisticated hunting strategies.

name: Genius Dinosaur
description: Passive: Learn enemy patterns. +10% damage per turn in combat (max 50%).
scientificNote: Troodon's brain case suggests intelligence comparable to modern ratites like ostriches.

name: Heavy Claw Swipe
description: Swipe with your massive thumb claw. High damage with bleeding chance.
scientificNote: Baryonyx means 'heavy claw', referring to its massive 31cm thumb claw used to hook fish.

name: Fish Hook Grab
description: Hook and pull an enemy closer. +30% damage on next attack against this target.
scientificNote: The thumb claw was likely used to hook fish from the water, similar to how bears fish.

name: Swarm Attack
description: Attack as a swarm. Deals damage based on how many swarm members remain.
scientificNote: Small theropods like Compsognathus likely hunted in groups to take down larger prey.

name: Quick Bite
description: Fast attack that always goes first. Low damage but reliable.
scientificNote: Small size and agility allowed for quick, darting attacks before prey could react.

name: Call Swarm
description: Call for reinforcements. Summon 2 additional swarm members.
scientificNote: Colonial nesting and pack behavior would have allowed quick coordination of multiple individuals.

name: Tiny Target
description: Passive: +5 evasion. Large enemies have -20% accuracy against you.
scientificNote: At just 1 meter long, Compsognathus was one of the smallest known non-avian dinosaurs.

name: Death Roll
description: Grab and spin your prey. Deals 180% damage and causes disorientation.
scientificNote: Modern crocodilians use the death roll to tear chunks from prey - ancient crocodilians likely did the same.

name: Ambush
description: Strike from hiding. 200% damage if target hasn't acted this combat.
scientificNote: Crocodilians are ambush predators, waiting motionless for prey to approach before striking.

name: Horn Charge
description: Lower your horns and charge. Deals 150% damage with knockback.
scientificNote: Triceratops' three horns could reach 1 meter in length and were used for defense and possibly combat with rivals.

name: Shield Stance
description: Raise your frill as a shield. +5 defense for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Triceratops' frill was made of solid bone and could serve as protection for the vulnerable neck.

name: Thagomizer
description: Swing your spiked tail. High damage with bleeding chance.
scientificNote: The term 'thagomizer' was coined by cartoonist Gary Larson and adopted by paleontologists for Stegosaurus' tail spikes.

name: Plate Display
description: Flush blood to your plates to intimidate. Enemies have -2 attack for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Stegosaurus plates were rich in blood vessels and may have flushed red for display or thermoregulation.

name: Armored Charge
description: Charge forward with your armored body, dealing 140% damage and gaining +2 defense for 1 turn.
scientificNote: Ankylosaurus could use its heavy body armor offensively, making a charging attack quite formidable.

name: Blitz Attack
description: Lightning-fast strike that always goes first and deals 130% damage.
scientificNote: Carnotaurus was built for speed, able to deliver devastating first strikes before prey could react.

name: Branch Pull
description: Use your long claws to pull and strike. Deals 110% damage and reduces enemy speed by 2 for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Therizinosaurus' enormous claws were likely used to pull down tree branches for feeding.

name: Claw Fury
description: Unleash a flurry of claw attacks. Deals 50% damage 4 times.
scientificNote: With meter-long claws, Therizinosaurus could deliver devastating slashing attacks in rapid succession.

name: Coordinated Takedown
description: Work with pack members to bring down large prey. Deals 180% damage if you have allies in combat.
scientificNote: Utahraptor likely hunted in coordinated packs, allowing them to take down prey much larger than themselves.

name: Defensive Crouch
description: Lower your body and raise your dome. +4 defense for 2 turns but -1 speed.
scientificNote: Pachycephalosaurus could present its thick skull dome as a shield against predator attacks.

name: Defensive Formation
description: Form a defensive line with allies. All allies gain +3 defense for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Hadrosaurs like Parasaurolophus lived in herds and likely used group defense strategies.

name: Disemboweling Kick
description: Deliver a devastating kick with your sickle claw. Deals 160% damage with 30% chance to cause severe bleeding.
scientificNote: Dromaeosaurid sickle claws were likely used to slash and disembowel prey rather than for pinning.

name: Evasive Dash
description: Quickly dash away from danger. +4 evasion for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Small, agile dinosaurs like Compsognathus relied on speed and evasion for survival.

name: Feint Attack
description: Fake an attack to create an opening. Next attack deals +40% damage.
scientificNote: Intelligent hunters like Troodon may have used feints and misdirection in their hunting strategies.

name: Fish Hook
description: Hook your target with conical teeth. Deals 120% damage and prevents escape for 1 turn.
scientificNote: Spinosaurus' conical teeth were ideal for gripping slippery fish, preventing them from escaping.

name: Intimidating Display
description: Spread your arms to appear larger. Enemies have -2 attack for 2 turns.
scientificNote: Therizinosaurus' bizarre proportions and enormous claws would have made for an intimidating display.

name: Intimidating Horns
description: Display your horns to frighten enemies. 30% chance to cause fear for 1 turn.
scientificNote: Carnotaurus' distinctive horns may have been used for display and intimidation.

name: Overwhelming Numbers
description: Swarm the enemy from all directions. Deals 150% damage if you have 3+ swarm members.
scientificNote: Small pack-hunting theropods could overwhelm larger prey through sheer numbers.

name: Stunning Ram
description: Ram into your target head-first. Deals 120% damage with 60% stun chance.
scientificNote: Pachycephalosaurus' thick skull dome could deliver stunning blows to predators or rivals.

name: Tail Strike
description: Swing your powerful tail. Deals 110% damage with 20% chance to stun.
scientificNote: Many dinosaurs used their tails as weapons, from the club of Ankylosaurus to the whip-like tails of sauropods.

name: Water Lunge
description: Lunge from the water to strike prey on land. Deals 150% damage from water terrain.
scientificNote: Semi-aquatic predators like Baryonyx could launch surprise attacks from the water's edge.
